A easy-to-handle and bi-functional solid water-tolerant catalyst with the balance of Brønsted acid site ( BAS) and Lewis acid site (LAS) is crucial for the efficient conversion of glucose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). In the work, the AACH@γ-AlOOH (designated as Ny@γ-AlOOH) catalysts were synthesized through the in-situ AACH substitution of γ-AlOOH, where the AlO6 octahedral units served as the wate - tolerant LAS with mild acid strength, while the unsaturated AlO5 pentahedral units acted as the weak BAS, together forming Lewis - Brønsted acid pairs at molecular- level proximity. Glucose turnover and HMF selectivity were enhanced due to the rapid fructose transfer from LAS to the adjacent BAS for its dehydration to HMF, facilitating LAS liberation for another glucose turnover. Under an optimized catalyst N4/11@γ-AlOOH, a high HMF yield of 73.8 % was obtained in biphasic system of 1-butanol / H2O - NaCl (20 wt%) at 140 °C for 3 h. Graphical Abstract Keywords Glucose HMF Boehmite Heterogeneous catalysis AACH Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ongoing conflict in Ukraine has exacerbated the global energy crisis, leading to a significant surge in petroleum prices. As a result, there is growing interest in developing technologies that leverage renewable feedstocks for the production of chemicals and fuels from non - fossil resources [1,2]. Carbohydrates, which constitute up to 75 % of annual biomass production and represent the largest natural source of carbon, show considerable potential for conversion into biomass platform chemicals due to their abundant availability and renewability [3–5]. Among these platform chemicals, HMF has garnered extensive research attention due to its versatile applications as a building block for synthesizing fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, biofuels, and polymer monomers. This versatility can be attributed to HMF’s multiple active functional groups, including hydroxyl, aldehyde, and furan ring structures [3,4]. Generally, the highest yields of HMF are achieved using fructose as the reactant through the elimination of three water molecules. However, glucose is a more favorable feedstock due to its cost -effectiveness, abundant availability, and economic accessibility [6]. Moreover, the conversion of oligo - and polysaccharides such as cellulose, starch, sucrose, or cellobiose into HMF involves an intermediate step where these compounds are first degraded into glucose [7]. Despite this, direct transformation of glucose into HMF presents greater challenges, resulting in significantly lower yields and selectivity compared to fructose, primarily due to its complex tandem reaction mechanism [8]. Consequently, extensive research has focused on the isomerization of glucose to fructose, catalyzed by Lewis acid catalysts, followed by the dehydration of fructose to HMF, facilitated by Brønsted acid catalysts, which has been demonstrated as an effective pathway [8–10]. However, achieving high yield and selectivity of HMF from glucose poses significant challenges, primarily due to the isomerization process catalyzed by Lewis acid catalysts, which has been identified as a critical initial step [9]. A moderate amount of Lewis acid is optimal for the glucose - to - fructose isomerization. Excessive use of Lewis acid can lead to undesirable side reactions, such as the polymerization of glucose with HMF, fructose, or other intermediates, resulting in the formation of oligomers, humins, and formic acid (FA) [10,11]. For example, Ordomsky et al. [12] demonstrated that an excess of LAS could lead to the formation of undesirable byproducts such as humins. The modification of solid catalysts with phosphoric acid significantly increased selectivity towards HMF due to the deactivation of unselective LAS. Jiang et al. [13] reported that the synergistic effect between BAS and LAS played a crucial role in glucose conversion. A strong BAS facilitated the decomposition of HMF into levulinic acid (LeA), subsequently forming methyl levulinate. Guo et al. [14], Catrinck et al. [15], and Sun et al. [16] achieved catalysts with a balanced ratio of LAS to BAS through controlling Nb / W, niobic acid (NbO) / niobium phosphate (NbP), and H2O / WO3, respectively. Guo et al. [17] investigated the impact of in-situ phosphoric acid - supported TiO2 on glucose - derived HMF production and showed that unsaturated tetrahedral TiO4 units with moderate LAS are essential for achieving high HMF yields. The combination of these unsaturated tetrahedral TiO4 units acting as moderate LAS sites and adjacent protonated phosphate groups acting as weak BAS sites resulted in both high glucose turnover and excellent selectivity towards HMF. Kadam et al. [18] employed NbOPO4-supported TiO2 as a catalyst for HMF production from C6 carbohydrates, demonstrating that the optimal catalytic performance was attributed to the highly crystalline NbOPO4 phase with tunable Brønsted and Lewis acidity. Wei et al. [19] further showed that a charcoal - based catalyst containing both Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites played a crucial role in efficiently converting biomass sugars (xylose, glucose, and fructose) into furan compounds. Wang et al. [20] also emphasized the significant influence of bifunctional solid acids on the conversion of glucose and fructose into HMF.Therefore, it is essential to utilize a catalyst that strikes a well balance between Lewis and Brønsted acidity (moderate Lewis acid and weak Brønsted acid) for efficient conversion of glucose or other lignocellulosic biomass into HMF. The utilization of homogeneous catalytic systems involving mineral salts such as AlCl3, CrCl3, CuCl2, and FeCl3 as Lewis acids, often in conjunction with inorganic acids like H3PO4, H2SO4, and HCl as Brønsted acids, has been extensively employed for the production of HMF from glucose [21–23]. However, these systems are hindered by several limitations, including difficulties in product separation, equipment corrosion, environmental pollution concerns among others [1–3]. In contrast, heterogeneous catalysts are favored due to their ease of separation and reusability, as well as their environmentally benign nature and positive impact on human health [1–3]. To date, a variety of solid acid catalysts containing both LAS and BAS have been developed for the conversion of glucose into HMF. These catalysts encompass metal - organic frameworks (MOFs), zeolites, sulfonated materials, superacids, metal oxides, phosphates, charcoal-based catalysts, and others [3,4,7,13–20]. In these studies, research efforts have predominantly focused on optimizing the balance between LAS and BAS to enhance both the yield and selectivity of HMF production [13–20]. However, the reported solid acid catalysts have predominantly been utilized in non-aqueous media for HMF production, such as ionic liquids and polar aprotic solvents [23–25]. This preference is driven by several key considerations: (i) Solid catalysts with LAS may experience deactivation via hydration processes in water, as observed with γ-Al2O3 and silicoaluminate zeolites [26–29]; (ii) Active sites on these catalysts could potentially leach into the aqueous phase during the reaction, as noted with sulfate and phosphate - supported catalysts [30]; (iii) Ionic liquids and polar aprotic solvents, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), not only enhance HMF production but also stabilize its structure, thereby preventing rehydration or polymerization reactions involving HMF or other intermediates like glucose and fructose, which can lead to the formation of by-products including levulinic acid (LeA), formic acid (FA), and humins [28,29]. Despite the potential of HMF in industrial applications, significant challenges remain, including high costs, high viscosity, and difficulties in separating HMF from high - boiling - point reaction media. Additionally, glucose feedstocks from bio - refineries are typically present as aqueous solutions, similar to the hydrolysis products of cellulose or starch [31]. Consequently, water is an ideal solvent for HMF production from glucose, offering a clean, cost - effective, and environmentally friendly alternative. Generally, a biphasic system consisting of aqueous and organic solvents has emerged as an optimal medium for extracting HMF into the organic phase while effectively inhibiting its degradation into undesirable byproducts [27,32,33]. Notably, researchers have employed strategies such as surface anchoring of active sites through bonding or developing novel catalysts via carbonization or polymerization methods to achieve water - tolerant catalysts and prevent deactivation caused by water [3,6,24,27]. However, these processes complicate catalyst preparation, increase costs, and limit their suitability for large - scale industrial applications. Therefore, it is crucial to develop a bifunctional acidic and water - tolerant solid catalyst that is easy to handle, low - cost, less toxic, and highly stable. γ-Al2O3 is extensively employed as an industrial catalyst and support owing to its abundant availability, cost - effectiveness, and commercial accessibility [28,29]. Currently, γ-Al2O3 is utilized as a catalyst for the conversion of various sugars into HMF. For instance, García-Sancho et al. [34] reported that when γ-Al2O3 is used as a support for Nb2O5, it enhances xylose dehydration conversion; however, it also promotes secondary reactions, leading to a notable decrease in furfural selectivity. Additionally, the researchers observed that calcium chloride significantly facilitates glucose conversion into HMF, achieving 96 % glucose conversion and 52 % HMF yield at 175 °C after 15 minutes, using 0.65 g CaCl2 ·g aq. sol.−1 and acidified γ-Al2O3 as the catalyst [28]. Zhang et al. [35] observed a significant enhancement in catalytic activity for glucose conversion into HMF after loading sulfonated carbon onto γ-Al2O3. Utilizing the optimal AlSC-1 catalyst (sulfonated carbon / γ-Al2O3 composites), they achieved an HMF yield of 62.3 % at 160 °C over a 4-hour reaction period. Cho et al. [36] demonstrated that adjusting tungsten content to control BAS concentration could optimize both glucose conversion and product selectivity in this cascade reaction. However, their studies indicated that isolated γ-Al2O3 exhibited unsatisfactory catalytic performance due to insufficient BAS, which impeded fructose dehydration into HMF, resulting in a relatively low HMF yield. To address this issue, they attempted to enhance the BAS of γ-Al2O3 by incorporating acidic substances such as niobic acid or sulfonic acid, thereby constructing bifunctional acid catalysts with both BAS and LAS to improve HMF yield. Despite these modifications, excessive LAS remained in γ-Al2O3, leading to suboptimal HMF yields below 65 % and selectivity below 70 %. Additionally, it is important to note that γ-Al2O3 exhibits limited water tolerance, undergoing rehydration above 150 °C to form boehmite (γ-AlOOH) [37]. γ-AlOOH serves as a precursor to γ-Al2O3, exhibiting superior hydrothermal stability compared to γ-Al2O3. Additionally, it is commercially available at a low cost [38,39]. In our previous studies [40,41], we observed that γ-AlOOH achieved an impressive HMF yield of 61.2 % with a glucose conversion of 98.6 % in DMSO under mild reaction conditions (130 °C for 3 h). This result underscores the suitability of γ-AlOOH for sugar dehydration into HMF due to its moderate LAS, which originate from the Al-O octahedral units (AlO6). In contrast, γ-Al2O3 possesses strong LAS derived from unsaturated Al-O tetrahedral units (AlO4). However, when transitioning from DMSO to other solvents such as water or water / DMSO mixtures (with a ratio of 1: 3), there was a significant decrease in HMF yield to 1.2 % and 20.3 %, respectively. These findings can be attributed to the absence of BAS in γ-AlOOH, which hinders rapid dehydration and promotes side reactions. Ammonium aluminum carbonate hydroxide (AACH), with the chemical formula NH4Al(OH)2CO3, serves as an alternative precursor for γ-Al2O3 [42]. Both AACH and γ-AlOOH exhibit orthorhombic unit cells but belong to different space groups; AACH belongs to the Imam space group, while γ-AlOOH is classified under the Cmcm space group [37–45]. The unit cells of AACH, AACH after removal of NH4 + and CO3 2-, and γ-AlOOH are illustrated in Scheme 1. The primary distinction between γ-AlOOH and AACH lies in their structural components: γ-AlOOH consists solely of AlO6 octahedra, whereas AACH incorporates both AlO6 octahedra and NH4O4-(OH)2 units along with CO3 2- groups. One oxygen atom from the CO3 2- group forms hydrogen bonds with two hydroxyl groups of AlO6 [37–45]. Due to the presence of NH4 + and CO3 2-, which are connected to the central AlO6 through hydrogen bonding and ionic interactions, these species can easily be lost into water or decompose at high temperatures or low concentrations, leading to instability in aqueous environments and the formation of unsaturated Al-O pentahedral units (AlO5). The presence of unsaturated AlO5 facilitates the linkage of hydroxyl groups within its H2O molecules, resulting in the formation of BAS [39–43]. However, compared to γ-AlOOH, AACH exhibits a significantly lower abundance of AlO6 octahedra, leading to a markedly reduced LAS density. This results in inferior catalytic performance. In our previous work [42], under DMSO conditions, the HMF yield obtained by AACH was only 8.73 %. Even with the addition of ionic liquid 1 - butyl - 3 - methylimidazolium chloride ([Bmim]+Cl-), the maximum HMF yield achieved was still limited to 52.17 %. Moreover, AACH is unstable in water due to the leaching of NH4 + and CO3 2-. Lafficher et al. [44] observed that excessive washing of AACH with water gradually transforms it into γ-AlOOH. Therefore, incorporating a certain amount of AACH into γ-AlOOH in-situ could potentially yield a catalyst that is easy to handle, bifunctional, and water - tolerant while maintaining a balanced ratio between moderate LAS and weak BAS. This approach would also ensure the structural integrity of AACH and maintain the catalyst's acid stability in aqueous environments. Previous studies have demonstrated that adjusting the molar ratio between NH4HCO3 and Al3+ (such as Al(NO3)3·9 H2O) under identical reaction conditions can lead to the formation of both γ-AlOOH and AACH [40,41,45]. These findings suggest the potential for developing a facile and bifunctional catalyst with a well - balanced distribution of moderate LAS and weak BAS through in - situ substitution of γ-AlOOH with AACH. In this study, a series of catalysts AACH@γ-AlOOH ( referred to as Ny@γ-AlOOH) were developed and employed for the conversion of glucose into HM. The objective was to design a facile, bifunctional, and water - tolerant catalyst with well - balanced BAS and LAS. The relationship between acidity, structure, and catalytic performance - including HMF yield, selectivity, glucose conversion, and carbon balance - was comprehensively examined. Additionally, various reaction conditions such as duration, temperature, catalyst loading, and solvent choice were systematically investigated. These findings collectively provide initial proof - of - concept for the integration of heterogeneous catalysis and biphasic solvent systems in the synthesis of bio-based furanics from cellulosic carbohydrates. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials HMF standard sample (AR) was acquired from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Glucose and fructose was supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Beijing, China). All other reagents were analytically pure pharmaceuticals from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd, and were used without purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The typical procedure for the synthesis of γ-AlOOH was conducted as follows [40,41]: Initially, 15 mmol of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water. Next, 30 mmol of NH4HCO3 was gradually added under vigorous stirring until a clear solution formed. The pH was then adjusted to 9 by the gradual addition of 25 % ammonia solution. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon - lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed tightly, and heated at 110 °C for 12 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solid product was collected via centrifugation and washed three times with deionized water. Finally, the catalyst (γ-AlOOH) was obtained after vacuum drying at 80 °C for 24 h. The synthesis procedure for Ny@γ-AlOOH closely resembled that of γ-AlOOH, with the key difference being the controlled NH4HCO3 / Al(NO3)3·9 H2O molar ratio achieved by adjusting the amount of NH4HCO3 added to a fixed quantity of Al(NO3)3·9 H2O [40,41,45]. In this process, a mixture containing 15 - X mmol Al(NO3)3·9 H2O and X mmol NH4HCO3 was introduced into 50 mL deionized water. Subsequently, 15 mmol NH4HCO3 was gradually added under vigorous stirring. The remaining reaction steps were identical to those employed in γ-AlOOH synthesis. Finally, Ny@γ-AlOOH was obtained via vacuum - drying at 80 °C for 24 h. Herein, y represents the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O in the initial mixture of 15 mmol Al(NO3)3·9 H2O and NH4HCO3 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder XRD patterns were determined using Panalytical X-ray Powder diffractometer (XRD) with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The data were recorded at a 2θ range of 5° to 80°. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) analysis was done with Nexus Nicolet Fourier Transform spectrometer (Madison, Wisconsin, USA) in the range of wavelengths of 4000–500 cm−1. Specific surface area and pore size were determined using Quantachrome Micromeritics Instrument (Norcross, GA, USA), Brunauer - Emmett -Teller (BET) equation and Barrett - Joyner - Halenda (BJH) method, as appropriate. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) of the samples were performed on TA thermal gravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen - atmosphere (SDT Q600, Newcastle, Delaware, USA). Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites were investigated via FT - IR pyridine adsorption technique (Py-FTIR; Nicolet, Madison, Wisconsin, USA). The IR spectra were recorded at a resolution of 4 cm−1 in the range of 1700 cm−1 to 1400 cm−1. Prior to measurements, the samples were degassed in air at 80 °C for 24 h under reduced pressure, cooled down, and then adsorbed in saturated pyridine atmosphere at room temperature for 8 h. After adsorption, the infrared spectrum was recorded with sample temperature fixed at 80 °C while outgassing [40–46]. The numbers of LAS and BAS were determined on the basis of the integral absorbance of the characteristic band at 1445 and 1545 cm−1, using integrated molar extinction coefficient 2.22 and 1.67 cm/umol−1 receptively [47,48]. The acid strength of the catalysts was measured by the acid-base neutralization titration. The experiment was performed by suspending 0.1 g of catalyst in 50 mL of 2 M NaCl aqueous solution and stirring for 24 h at room temperature. The suspension was then titrated with 0.02 M NaOH standard solution using phenol red as an indicator [49]. X- ray photo - electron - spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, equipped with a monochromatic small - spot X - ray source and a 180◦ double focusing hemi - spherical analyzer with a 128-channel detector [46]. The morphology and particle size of the catalysts were checked by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-4800, JEOL) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100UHR, JEOL). The coordination of Al was examined by 27Al MAS NMR measurements ( Bruker DSC 400 Hz). The samples were packed into a 4 mm zirconia rotor and spun at 12 kHz. The resonance frequency for 27Al was 104.2 MHz [46]. The Al and N contents of the various Ny@γ-AlOOH samples were analyzed using X - ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF, ARLCorp., ADVANT’XP, Switzerland). The analysis was performed with an end - window 4 kW Rh X - ray tube operating at 50 kV and 80 mA. The contents of C (CO3 2-) and N (NH4 +) of the fresh and reused catalysts were checked by a by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP - OES, Agilent720ES) [17]. 2.4 Typical procedure in the production of HMF from glucose The reactions were carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer. In a typical procedure, 100 mg of glucose was dissolved in 20 mL of either a monophasic or biphasic reaction medium, including DMSO, DMF, H2O, 1-butanol/H2O - NaCl (20 wt% NaCl aqueous solution), THF/H2O - NaCl (20 wt% NaCl aqueous solution), and MIBK/H2O - NaCl (20 wt% NaCl aqueous solution), to achieve a substrate concentration of 5 g/L. The volume ratio of water to the organic phase was maintained at 1: 2 (v/v). After complete dissolution of glucose, 30 mg of catalyst was added to the mixture, resulting in a catalyst loading of 30 wt% relative to the glucose. The reaction mixture was then heated to 140 °C and allowed to proceed for 3.0 h. Following this, the autoclave was rapidly cooled to room temperature by immersion in an ice - water bath. The mixture was subsequently centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 10 min to separate the solid and liquid phases. The liquid fraction, comprising both organic and aqueous phases, was diluted approximately 150–200 times for analysis of product distribution and concentrations. The solid residue (spent catalyst) was washed multiple times with deionized water and ethanol, dried at 60 °C for 24 h, and then weighed, collected, and reused as a catalyst in recycling experiments. 2.5 HPLC Analysis Following filtration through a 0.22 μm filter, the collected liquids, including both organic and aqueous phases, were analyzed using High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC, Agilent 1200, USA). The concentrations of HMF and organic acids (LeA and FA) were quantified using an HPLC system equipped with an HC - C18 column (5 μm, 4.6 × 250 mm) and a UV detector set at 210 nm [50,51]. The mobile phase was composed of 5 mM H2SO4, flowing at a rate of 0.5 mL/min, with the column temperature maintained at 35 °C. Additionally, glucose and fructose concentrations were determined using HPLC coupled with an evaporative light - scattering detector (ELSD) under identical conditions [50,51]. Calibration curves derived from standard solutions of known concentrations were utilized to quantify the components in both aqueous and organic samples. Glucose conversion, HMF yield, and carbon balance (CB) were calculated as follows: Glucose conversion % = 100 % − Mole of glucose in product Mole of glucose × 100 % HMF yield % = Mole of HMF in product Mole of glucose × 100 % C arbon balance % = The sum of the carbon mass present in all the reaction products The mass of carbon present in the converted glucose × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst The precondition for this study is the synthesis of γ-AlOOH. Therefore, the effects of reaction conditions, specifically the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O and pH, were investigated (Fig. S1). It was observed that higher molar ratios and elevated pH levels were detrimental to the formation of γ-AlOOH. Equations 1–5 illustrate the formation processes of AlOOH and AACH (NH4Al(OH)2CO3) in an Al(NO3)3 and NH4HCO3 solution. A higher pH promotes the formation of Al(OH)4 - according to Equation 3 but inhibits the production of γ-AlOOH based on Equations 2 and 5 due to chemical equilibrium considerations. Notably, Al(OH)4 - plays a crucial role in the formation of AACH as described by Equations 4 and 5. Additionally, a higher molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O favors the formation of AACH according to Equations 4 and 5.( Scheme 2) The primary objective of this study is to achieve a Ny@γ-AlOOH catalyst with an optimally balanced ratio of BAS and LAS (moderate LAS and weak BAS) by precisely adjusting the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O in a 15 mmol mixture. Fig. 1 presents the XRD results of the Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts. It was observed that AACH formation only occurred when the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O in the 15 mmol mixture was at least 7: 8, resulting in a total molar ratio of 4.6:1. These findings align with previous studies [42–45] and the results shown in Fig. S1, which highlight the critical role of the total molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O in AACH synthesis. Specifically, AACH formation requires a total molar ratio approaching or exceeding 4: 1, as lower ratios result in insufficient concentrations of Al(OH)4 - and NH4HCO3, leading to inadequate production of AACH nuclei. Therefore, it is recommended to maintain the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O at or below 7: 8. The Py - FTIR adsorption technique was utilized to differentiate and quantify the BAS and LAS on the synthesized Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts ( Fig. 2 and Table 1). According to previous studies [10–16], characteristic peaks at wavenumbers of approximately 1445 cm−1 and 1554 cm−1 were observed for LAS and BAS, respectively. Additionally, peaks at around 1486 cm−1 indicated the interaction of pyridine with both types of acid sites. From Fig. 2 and Table 1, it is evident that the intensity and area of the bands at 1445 cm−1, representing the amount of LAS derived from AlO6 in Ny@γ-AlOOH, gradually decreased as the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increased. This decrease can be attributed to the gradual transformation of γ-AlOOH to AACH due to the increasing NH4HCO3 / Al(NO3)3·9 H2O molar ratio [42–45,52], leading to a reduction in the number of AlO6 units and consequently a decrease in LAS. Conversely, the emergence of bands at 1554 cm−1 in N2/13@γ-AlOOH samples indicates an increase in BAS derived from AlO5 on Ny@γ-AlOOH. The intensity and area of these bands increased until a NH4HCO3 / Al(NO3)3·9 H2O ratio of 7: 8 was reached, after which they decreased. This behavior is likely associated with the formation of AACH. Scheme 3 illustrates this process. Initially, as the concentration of NH4HCO3 increased, hydrogen bonds between γ-AlOOH grains began to break, leading to the decomposition of γ-AlOOH into smaller grains and their subsequent reaction with NH4HCO3 to form AACH grains (as shown in processes A and B in Scheme 3). At this stage, AACH particles were fully exposed to water, facilitating interactions between NH4 + and CO3 2- on their surface with water molecules, resulting in the appearance of unsaturated AlO5 and the initiation of BAS formation. Subsequently, with further increases in NH4HCO3 concentration, both the number and size of AACH grains grew, accompanied by an increased loss of surface NH4 + and CO3 2-, leading to an elevation in BAS. However, when the size of AACH grains reached a certain threshold, they underwent self - assembly and crystallization processes, forming regular - shaped AACH crystals such as rod-shaped ones (as illustrated by processes C and D in Scheme 3). During this stage, the decrease in surface NH4 + and CO3 2- reduced their loss rate, leading to a corresponding reduction in AlO5 and BAS. 27Al MAS NMR spectroscopy was employed to investigate the local aluminum environment of the Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts ( Fig. 3). The resulting NMR spectra displayed two distinct peaks at chemical shifts of 8.0 ppm and 38 ppm, respectively. These peaks were attributed to differences in electron density around the aluminum nucleus caused by neighboring atoms. Specifically, the peak at 8.0 ppm corresponds to the characteristic AlO6, while the peak at 38 ppm indicates the presence of AlO5 [42–46]. Consistent with previous studies [42–46], the occurrence of AlO6 is associated with LAS in Al-based catalysts, whereas AlO5 signifies BAS. Higher peak areas for either AlO6 or AlO5 indicate a greater abundance of LAS or BAS, respectively. The ratios of the peak area at 38 ppm (representing AlO5) to that at 8.0 ppm (representing AlO6) for the Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts are summarized in Table 1 and illustrated in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3 and Table 1, an increase in the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O results in a decrease in the LAS represented by the peak area at 8.0 ppm. Meanwhile, the peak area at 38 ppm, representing BAS, initially increased and then decreased with increasing molar ratio [42–46]. This observation is consistent with the Py - FTIR results; however, several discrepancies are noted. First, the peak area ratio of AlO5 to AlO6 was significantly lower than the BAS / LAS ratio observed in the Py - FTIR analysis. Second, although Py - FTIR indicated the presence of BAS on the surface of N9/6@γ-AlOOH and N10/5@γ-AlOOH catalysts, no absorption peak at 38 ppm corresponding to BAS was detected by 27Al MAS NMR for these two catalysts. Finally, different catalysts exhibited varying BAS / LAS ratios. In Py - FTIR analysis, this ratio was highest for N7/8@γ-AlOOH, whereas in 27Al MAS NMR analysis, it was highest for N5/10@γ-AlOOH. These differences can be attributed to Py-FTIR characterizing the surface acidity of the catalysts, while 27Al MAS NMR reflects their bulk acidity. The morphology of the Ny@γ-AlOOH catalyst was characterized using SEM and TEM techniques ( Fig. 4). Analysis of the SEM images (Fig. 4(a-j)) revealed a gradual transformation in the catalyst morphology from an initial flake - like accumulation (e.g., nano - flower in Fig. 4(a)) to a rod - like structure (e.g., long rod in Fig. 4(j)), as the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increased. Previous studies [42–46] have reported that AACH and γ-AlOOH possess orthorhombic unit cells with different space groups: Imam for AACH, with unit parameters a= 6.566 Å, b= 11.925 Å, c= 5.717 Å; and Cmcm for γ-AlOOH, with unit parameters a= 3.70 Å, b= 12.23 Å, c= 2.87 Å. Consequently, γ-AlOOH tends to form sheet structures along the (010) crystal plane, while AACH exhibits preferential growth along the (001) and (100) crystal faces, leading to the formation of rod - like structures. The observed changes in catalyst morphology through SEM analysis are consistent with the crystal structure transition from γ-AlOOH to AACH, as illustrated in Scheme 3. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of the samples, as shown in Fig. 5(A), exhibit a type IV isotherm for all samples. However, the hysteresis loops vary with increasing molar ratios of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O. For molar ratios below 4: 11 (e.g., N2/13@γ-AlOOH, N4/11@γ-AlOOH), typical H3 hysteresis loops are observed, indicating the formation of slit - shaped mesopores from non - rigid agglomerates of flake grains [27,38,42,52]. Conversely, as the molar ratio exceeds 4: 11, a gradual transition to H4 hysteresis loops becomes evident. Clear H4 hysteresis loops were observed between P/P0 values of 0.45 and 0.89 for molar ratios of 9: 6 (N9/6@γ-AlOOH) and 10: 5 (N10/5@γ-AlOOH), suggesting a morphological transformation from flake to block or rod - like structures and an increase in micropore areas [41–43,49]. These findings align with the SEM and TEM observations presented in Fig. 4, which show that the catalyst morphology transitions from a flake structure to a rod - like structure as the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increases. Additionally, the surface of γ-AlOOH in Fig. 4(i) appears smooth, while the surface of AACH in Fig. 4(j) exhibits numerous micropores due to the loss of NH4 + and CO3 2- [44–46,52]. The pore size distribution, depicted in Fig. 5(B), shows that when the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O is below 4: 11, most pores are centered around 4.0 nm, resulting from the accumulation of small nanosheets. Only a few pores extend up to 22 nm, attributed to the aggregation of nanosheets forming block - like structures resembling nanoflowers as shown in Fig. 4(a). For molar ratios exceeding 4: 11, larger pores gradually diminish, and the majority of observed pores are approximately 4.0 and 8.0 nm in size, attributed to self - aggregation of nanoparticles such as nano - rods. The samples were further characterized by FT - IR as shown in Fig. 6. When the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O was less than 4: 11, all observed peaks corresponded to characteristic vibrations of γ-AlOOH. Specifically, the bands at 3310 cm−1 and 3095 cm−1 were attributed to asymmetric (νas) and symmetric (νs) stretching vibrations of (Al)O–H, respectively, while the bands at 1072 cm−1 and 1162 cm−1 corresponded to symmetric (δs) and asymmetric (δas) bending vibrations of Al–O–H. The bands at 751 cm−1, 630 cm−1, and 484 cm−1 indicated the vibration modes of AlO6 [40]. Conversely, when the molar ratio exceeded 4: 11, peaks associated with AACH vibrations gradually emerged. At a molar ratio of 7: 8 or higher, all peaks could be exclusively assigned to AACH vibrations. Notably, when the molar ratio reached 10: 5, N10/5@γ-AlOOH exhibited distinct peaks corresponding to OH, NH4 +, CO3 2-, and AlO6 vibrations. Specifically, the bands at 3445 cm−1 and 985 cm−1 were attributed to ν OH and δ OH vibrations, respectively. The bands at 3175 cm−1, 3018 cm−1, and 2840 cm−1 corresponded to ν NH stretching vibrations, while the band at 1723 cm−1 represented δ NH bending vibrations. Additionally, the bands at 1545 cm−1, 1452 cm−1, and 1382 cm−1 were assigned to ν3 of CO3 2-, and the bands at 1105 cm−1, 850 cm−1, and 760 cm−1 indicated ν1, ν2, and ν4 of CO3 2-. Finally, the vibration modes of AlO6 were characterized by three bands located at 751 cm−1, 630 cm−1, and 484 cm−1 [44,52]. These findings are consistent with the XRD and SEM results discussed earlier. The TGA analysis of Ny@γ-AlOOH conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere ( Fig. 7A) revealed a progressive decrease in residual ash content for the catalysts, which correlates with an increased molar ratio between NH4HCO3 and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O. This trend can be attributed to the structural transformation of γ-AlOOH into AACH as the molar ratio increases. Fig. 7(B) shows the DTG patterns of Ny@γ-AlOOH, indicating that the weight loss peak associated with γ-AlOOH, particularly for N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH catalysts, is primarily centered around 500 °C due to dehydration leading to γ-Al2O3 formation [39–42]. The weight losses for both N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH during this process were approximately 15 %, aligning with the theoretically expected weight loss of 15 % during the conversion from γ-AlOOH to γ-Al2O3. In contrast, for AACH catalysts (N9/6@γ-AlOOH and N10/5@γ-AlOOH), the weight loss peak was observed at a lower temperature zone around 251 °C, primarily due to the release of CO2, NH3, and H2O during the transformation from AACH to γ-Al2O3 [42–46]. The weight losses of these AACH catalysts were found to be as high as approximately 63 %, which is in close agreement with the theoretical weight loss of 61 % upon the transformation of AACH into γ-Al2O3. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 7(B), an increase in the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O from 2: 13 resulted in the emergence of a distinct weight loss peak at a lower temperature range around 200 ℃, in addition to the weight loss peak at approximately 550 ℃ observed in the N2/13@γ-AlOOH catalyst. Further analysis indicated that as the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increased, both the intensity and area of the weight loss peak at the lower temperature zone (around 200 ℃) progressively increased, while those at approximately 550 ℃ gradually diminished. When the molar ratio reached 9: 6 and 10: 5 for NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O respectively, only weight loss peaks at the lower temperature zones remained, with those around 550 ℃ disappearing. Moreover, it was observed that the weight loss peak gradually shifted from 200 ℃ to 251 ℃ as the proportion increased. This shift supports the conclusion that Ny@γ-AlOOH underwent a gradual transformation from γ-AlOOH to AACH with an increasing molar ratio of NH4HCO3 and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O. According to Scheme 3, which illustrates the formation process of AACH, this transformation can be divided into three stages: the nucleation and growth of AACH grains, followed by their self - assembly, and finally their crystallization into larger AACH crystals. Consequently, in the initial stage (at low molar ratios), AACH grains exhibited incomplete crystallization, leading to easier conversion to γ-Al2O3 at lower temperatures. As the molar ratios increased, AACH grains progressively grew and fully crystallized, resulting in their subsequent self - assembly into larger crystals. This phenomenon accounts for the observed shift in the transformation temperature towards higher values for γ-Al2O3. X - ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is a highly effective characterization technique for elucidating the elemental composition and chemical valence states of the as - synthesized Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts. Fig. 8(A) shows that, based on the comprehensive survey scan, N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH consisted exclusively of Al and O, with no detectable presence of C or N. However, an increase in the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O from 2: 13 introduced the presence of C. Further increasing this molar ratio to 4: 11 resulted in the appearance of N. Consequently, all catalysts at higher molar ratios exhibited a four - element composition comprising Al, O, C, and N. Moreover, exceeding a molar ratio of 4: 11 led to a gradual increase in the intensity of the C and N peaks. This observation indicates that both N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH catalysts exhibit γ-AlOOH structures. As the molar ratio increases beyond this point, the structure of Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts gradually transitions from γ-AlOOH to AACH. These findings align with the previously discussed XRD and FT-IR results. Fig. 9 B - D shows the corresponding high - resolution XPS spectra for Al 2p, O 1 s, and C 1 s. In Fig. 8(B), the Al 2p peaks were deconvoluted into two distinct peaks at 74.2 and 74.9 eV, corresponding to surface Al-OH and Al-O-Al (AlO6) [42,53–56]. Additionally, it was observed that the Al-O-Al (AlO6) peaks in N4/11@γ-AlOOH and N5/10@γ-AlOOH shifted to lower binding energies, suggesting the presence of unsaturated Al-O-Al bonds such as AlO5 in these samples. The O 1 s spectrum in Fig. 8(C) displays three well - defined peaks at 531.3, 532.3, and 533.3 eV, which can be attributed to crystal lattice oxygen (Al-O-Al), and two types of surface hydroxyl (-OH) groups (Al-O-H and C-O-H bonds), respectively [42,53–56]. Moreover, it was observed that the Al-O-Al peaks in both N4/11@γ-AlOOH and N5/10@γ-AlOOH shifted to lower binding energies. In Fig. 4(D), distinct peaks at 284.2, 285.5, and 287.7 eV corresponding to C-O-(H), C-O-(Al), and CO bonds were identified in the C1s spectrum [42,53–56]. These observations collectively indicate that as the molar ratio increases, the catalyst Ny@γ-AlOOH gradually transforms from γ-AlOOH to AACH. During this transformation, the initial stage of AACH formation is characterized by small grain size and low crystallinity, leading to the easy loss of CO3 2- and NH4 + on the surface of Ny@γ-AlOOH. Consequently, Al-O-Al peaks appear at lower binding energies. Once AACH grains grow and self - assemble into more crystalline structures, the exposed ratio of CO3 2- and NH4 + on the surface decreases, making them less susceptible to loss and thus reducing the occurrence of Al-O-Al peaks at lower binding energies. The composition of Ny@γ-AlOOH is summarized in Table 2. Theoretically, γ-AlOOH catalyst contains 45 % Al and 53 % O. For AACH, the theoretical composition includes 19.42 % Al, 57.55 % O, 10.07 % N, and 8.60 % C. According to Table 2, XPS analysis indicates that N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH catalysts consist solely of Al and O, whereas all other catalysts contain four elements: Al, O, C, and N. XRF results show that the Al content in N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH is approximately 44.58 % and 44.16 %, respectively, which closely matches the theoretical value of 45 % for γ-AlOOH. This supports the conclusion that both N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH exhibit a γ-AlOOH structure. However, XPS data reveal that the Al percentages in N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH are 40.56 % and 38.89 %, respectively, lower than the theoretical 45 %. Conversely, their oxygen contents are higher at 59.44 % and 61.11 %, respectively, compared to the theoretical 53 %. This discrepancy may stem from the fact that XPS primarily measures surface properties of catalysts. Given the presence of numerous OH groups and a small amount of adsorbed water on the surface of γ-AlOOH, this leads to an observed increase in oxygen content and a relative decrease in aluminum content during XPS analysis. As the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increases, both the aluminum content and the levels of carbon and nitrogen gradually rise. At molar ratios of 9: 6 (N9/6@γ-AlOOH) and 10: 5 (N10/5@γ-AlOOH), XRF analysis determined their respective aluminum and nitrogen contents to be 20.03 %, 19.58 % and 9.16 %, 9.57 %, which closely align with the theoretical values for AACH at 19.42 % for aluminum and 10.07 % for nitrogen. The present findings provide further evidence to support the conclusion that an increasing molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O progressively transforms the catalyst structure from γ-AlOOH to AACH form. XPS analysis revealed significantly lower nitrogen (N) levels compared to those obtained via XRF analysis; however, this discrepancy decreases as the molar ratio of NH4HCO3 to Al(NO3)3·9 H2O increases. These observations suggest that surface - bound nitrogen species (NH4 +) are prone to loss during XPS analysis, resulting in a lower recorded nitrogen content relative to XRF measurements. Additionally, as the molar ratio increases, the rate of nitrogen loss diminishes, thereby narrowing the disparity between the two analytical methods. 3.2 Degradation of glucose into HMF Table 3 provides a comparative analysis of the catalytic efficiency of N4/11@γ-AlOOH relative to current state - of - the - art catalysts for glucose conversion to HMF. The data indicate that N4/11@γ-AlOOH (entries 21–23) demonstrates superior catalytic performance in converting glucose to HMF. Without the N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst, only a modest yield of 5.3 % HMF (entry 23) was achieved, with a glucose conversion of just 38.7 %. In contrast, the addition of N4/11@γ-AlOOH resulted in significantly higher HMF yields of 80.7 % (entry 22) and 73.8 % (entry 21), with complete glucose conversion in both single - phase DMSO systems and biphasic systems using 1-butanol and H2O, respectively, aided by a salting - out effect induced by a 20 % NaCl solution. It is important to note that the influence of solvents on the reaction will be discussed in detail in the subsequent section. While the performance of N4/11@γ-AlOOH is comparable to those reported in references [25,57] (Entries 6 and 12), these referenced catalysts suffer from several limitations, including complex preparation processes, high costs, and environmental concerns due to their reliance on toxic and corrosive metals such as Sn, which hinder large - scale HMF production. The proposed reaction mechanism for the conversion of glucose to HMF via tandem catalysis over Lewis acid and Brønsted acid is illustrated in Scheme 4. In this process, glucose undergoes isomerization to fructose, facilitated by the Lewis acid, followed by the dehydration of fructose to HMF and subsequent rehydration of HMF to formic acid (FA) and levulinic acid (LeA), assisted by the Brønsted acid. It should be noted that sugars such as glucose and fructose, along with HMF, can also degrade into formic acid (FA) or polymerize into soluble oligomers or insoluble humins, both in the presence and absence of catalysts. Additionally, under the influence of Lewis acid, fructose can be cleaved into lactic acid (LA). However, alternative pathways, such as the direct dehydration of glucose to L-glucosone followed by its conversion to HMF without an isomerization step, have been excluded from consideration due to the consistent observation of fructose throughout all experiments listed in Table 4. The catalytic effects of Ny@γ-AlOOH on the production of HMF from glucose in a 1-butanol / H2O -NaCl biphasic system at 140 °C for 3 h are presented in Table 4. Based on the aforementioned discussion, it is evident that both N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH possess γ-AlOOH structures exclusively containing LAS. Their respective HMF yields were determined to be 55.6 % and 57.8 %, with a glucose conversion of 100 % (entries 2 and 3). Although the catalytic performances of N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH were superior to that in the absence of catalyst (entry 1), they exhibited relatively lower activity compared to N2/13@γ-AlOOH, N5/10@γ-AlOOH, and particularly N4/11@γ-AlOOH. This result can be attributed to the fact that N2/13@γ-AlOOH, N5/10@γ-AlOOH, and N4/11@γ-AlOOH possess both LAS and BAS bifunctionalities, whereas N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH only contain LAS. Consequently, the rapid transfer of fructose from LAS to BAS for its dehydration to HMF is hindered in N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH. Furthermore, the carbon balances of N0/15@γ-AlOOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH remained below 60 %, which is lower than all other Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts with LAS and BAS bifunctionalities, such as N2/13@γ-AlOOH (65.3 %), N5/10@γ-AlOOH (65.9 %), N10/5@γ-AlOOH (65.1 %), and especially N4/11@ γ-Al OOH (73.8 %). This observation indicates significant humins formation under the conditions of only LAS in N0/15@ γ-Al OOH and N1/14@γ-AlOOH. These findings suggest that isolated LAS can facilitate glucose conversion into HMF but with reduced selectivity [17–29]. To elucidate their correlation, we investigated the relationship between acidity (BAS and LAS) and HMF production from glucose. The glucose conversions were analyzed based on the LAS amount and total acidity, while the HMF yield, selectivity, and carbon balance were assessed using the BAS to LAS ratio of Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts (Fig. 9). As shown in Fig. 9A and B, glucose conversion exhibited a direct proportionality with both the LAS amount and total acidity. Given that all Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts had significantly higher levels of LAS compared to BAS (Table 1), it can be inferred that glucose conversion was predominantly influenced by the quantity of LAS. However, as illustrated in Fig. 9(C), the correlation between HMF selectivity or carbon balance and the molar ratio of BAS / LAS initially increased and then decreased. For example, at a BAS / LAS molar ratio of 0, HMF selectivity and carbon balance were approximately 56 % and 66 %, respectively. Increasing the molar ratio to 0.03 resulted in an HMF selectivity of 65.3 % and a carbon balance of 71.4 %. When the BAS / LAS molar ratio reached 0.11, both HMF selectivity (73.8 %) and carbon balance (78 %) were maximized. Subsequently, once the BAS / LAS molar ratio exceeded the threshold, both HMF selectivity and carbon balance rapidly declined until they stabilized at approximately 65 % and 71 %, respectively, for a molar ratio of BAS / LAS greater than or equal to 0.16. This observation highlights the critical importance of maintaining an optimal balance between BAS and LAS to facilitate efficient glucose conversion into HMF. However, discerning the intuitive relationship between the BAS / LAS molar ratio and HMF yield from Fig. 9(C) was challenging. Therefore, this study examined the correlation among LAS concentration, BAS / LAS molar ratio, and HMF yield as illustrated in Fig. 9(D). It was observed that increasing the BAS / LAS molar ratio led to higher HMF yields when the LAS concentration exceeded 98.5 μmol pyridine/g. Conversely, below this concentration, no direct correlation between the BAS/LAS molar ratio and HMF yield was evident; instead, the quantity of LAS directly influenced HMF production, with decreasing LAS amounts resulting in reduced HMF yields. Previous studies [9–17] have consistently demonstrated that glucose isomerization into fructose, catalyzed by LAS, serves as the primary and pivotal step in converting glucose to HMF. This process requires higher energy compared to fructose dehydration into HMF, which is catalyzed by BAS. Junior et al. [66] investigated the kinetics of glucose conversion to HMF using niobium phosphate and found that fructose dehydration to HMF exhibited the lowest activation energy (25 kJ/mol), while glucose isomerization to fructose required a significantly higher activation energy of 86 kJ/mol. Consequently, reducing the LAS content up to a certain threshold (98.5 μmol pyridine/g) would inevitably lead to a substantial decline in LAS activity on Ny@γ-AlOOH catalysts (as observed in Table 1). This reduction would subsequently result in a rapid decrease in glucose conversion (isomerization into fructose), as evidenced by the results shown in Fig. 9(A), leading to reduced fructose production and ultimately negatively impacting HMF generation. In general, the conversion of glucose showed a positive correlation with the amount of LAS, while HMF selectivity was positively correlated with the molar ratio of BAS to LAS. Therefore, high yields of HMF can only be achieved when the LAS content in the catalyst exceeds a specific threshold, which requires precise control of the molar ratio of BAS to LAS. 3.3 Proximity between LAS and BAS The proximity effect between LAS and BAS was examined in this section by comparing the catalytic performance of physical combinations of Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts, specifically N0/15@γ-AlOOH + H3PO4 or N0/15@γ-AlOOH + Amberlyst 16, with N4/11@γ-AlOOH in a biphasic system consisting of 1-butanol and H2O - NaCl (20 wt% NaCl aqueous solution, with a volume ratio of H2O to 1-butanol of 1: 2 V/V). The reactions were conducted at 120 °C for 12 h to avoid thermal decomposition of Amberlyst-16, which occurs above 130 °C. For each catalyst combination, the amounts of LAS and BAS were adjusted to match those of N4/11@γ-AlOOH based on the pyridine-IR results presented in Table 1. Thus, the key difference between N4/11@γ-AlOOH and these catalyst combinations is the spatial proximity of LAS and BAS. N0/15@γ-AlOOH, featuring a γ-AlOOH structure, served as a benchmark to represent the mono - functional solid Lewis acid catalyst. The loading of N0/15@γ-AlOOH was adjusted to match the LAS content in other catalyst combinations. The results are summarized in Fig. 10. It can be concluded that the cooperative effect between LAS and BAS is critically dependent on their spatial proximity. While separated BAS (e.g., in N0/15@γ-AlOOH+H3PO4 or N0/15@γ-AlOOH+Amberlyst 16) can enhance HMF yield, it has a limited impact on overall glucose conversion activity. In contrast, when BAS is in close proximity to LAS (e.g., in N4/11@γ-AlOOH), both activity and HMF selectivity are significantly improved due to rapid fructose transfer to BAS for dehydration into HMF. This reduces fructose occupancy on LAS, thereby minimizing humins formation and increasing the accessibility of LAS for subsequent glucose turnover. Catalytic performances using physical mixtures of N10/5@γ-AlOOH and N0/15@γ-AlOOH as catalysts are also shown in Fig. S2. It was observed that simple physical mixtures of LAS and BAS catalysts exhibited poor catalytic performance, underscoring the critical importance of spatial proximity between LAS and BAS for efficient glucose conversion into HMF. 3.4 Optimization of reaction parameters 3.4.1 Reaction solvent Solvents play indispensable roles in chemical reactions. As illustrated in Fig. 11, the presence of H2O resulted in a significantly reduced yield of HMF and low selectivity towards HMF. This can be attributed to the inherent instability of HMF in an aqueous environment, which leads to its decomposition into LeA and FA, as well as polymerization into byproducts such as oligomers and humins [17–23]. One strategy involves utilizing protic polar organic solvents, such as N, N - dimethylformamide (DMF) and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), along with ionic liquids, particularly imidazolium - based ionic liquids (ILs) like 1 - butyl - 3 - methylimidazolium chloride ([Bmim]Cl), as reaction media. These solvents enhance the production of HMF from carbohydrates by effectively solvating HMF, thereby minimizing its interaction with intermediates or water molecules. This stabilization prevents undesired side reactions, leading to higher yields and selectivity [7,28,29]. Studies comparing different solvents in the reaction system, including DMF, DMSO, and an ionic liquid (IL), revealed that these solvents significantly improve HMF yield and selectivity compared to water (Fig. 11). Notably, DMSO achieved both high HMF yield (80.7 %) and selectivity due to its dual role: stabilizing HMF by preventing its decomposition into undesired byproducts while also promoting the conversion of carbohydrates into HMF [7,28,29]. For example, Amarasekara et al. [67] reported that in DMSO, when the reaction temperature was set at 150°C, the anomeric composition of D - fructose shifted, with a slight increase in the α - furanose form at the expense of the β - pyranose tautomer. Additionally, a minor presence of the α - pyranose form was also observed at this temperature. A key intermediate identified through 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy was (4 R, 5 R) - 4 - hydroxy - 5 - (hydroxymethyl) - 2 -tetrahydrofuranecarb- aldehyde. This study demonstrated the catalytic potential of DMSO in the conversion of fructose to HMF. Moreover, due to its lower viscosity compared to ionic liquids (ILs), DMSO exhibited enhanced efficiency in facilitating the transfer of substrates such as glucose and enabling effective separation of target products like HMF. An alternative approach entails the use of aqueous and organic solvents to extract HMF into the organic phase, thereby preventing its further degradation into other byproducts [27,32,33]. Four organic solvents — 1-butanol, 1-hexanol, MIBK, and THF — were selected as extracting agents in the biphasic system. MIBK and THF are widely recognized for their effectiveness in extracting HMF from water into the organic phase while minimizing undesirable side reactions [27,57]. Additionally, 1-hexanol and 1-butanol have been frequently employed as organic solvents in biphasic systems for HMF production [68]. Notably, 1-butanol is particularly advantageous for biomass applications because it can be derived from biomass fermentation [69]. Previous studies [27,57,64,69] have demonstrated that the addition of salt enhances the partitioning of HMF into the extracting phase through a salting - out effect, thereby increasing HMF yield. Mohammad et al. [70] and Dalmolin et al. [71] investigated the impact of common salts on HMF in biphasic systems and reported an enhanced salting - out effect in the following order: NaCl > Na2SO4 > KCl > K2SO4, with NaCl identified as the most effective salting - out agent. Xie et al. [72] examined the influence of salt concentration on this effect in a THF - H2O biphasic system and found that a 20 wt% NaCl concentration yielded optimal results. Consequently, we adopted a 20 wt% NaCl concentration in our biphasic systems. The conversion of glucose to HMF in different biphasic systems (with or without NaCl in the aqueous phase) is summarized in Table S1. It was observed that the presence of NaCl significantly influenced and enhanced the extraction equilibrium of HMF in the aqueous phase for all tested organic solvents, including 1-butanol, 1-hexanol, MIBK, and THF. Specifically, the addition of NaCl resulted in a higher partition coefficient R (the ratio of HMF weight fraction in the organic phase to that in the aqueous phase) compared to non - salt systems. Moreover, it was observed that the R - values were influenced by both solvent properties and NaCl addition [70–72]. Specifically, for the systems 1-butanol/H2O, 1-hexanol/H2O, MIBK/H2O, and THF/H2O, the R - values were determined to be 1.7, 0.9, 1.1, and 1.4, respectively. The corresponding HMF yields were 61.3 %, 45.3 %, 50.6 %, and 55.3 %, respectively. Furthermore, upon adding NaCl to these solvents, the R - values increased significantly to 3.6, 1.6, 2.1, and 3.0, respectively, resulting in higher HMF yields of approximately 73.8 %, 53.1 %, 58.9 %, and 65.3 %. These results indicate a positive correlation between the R - value and both HMF yield and selectivity, suggesting that enhancing the efficiency of HMF extraction from the aqueous phase can effectively mitigate undesired side reactions. Notably, among the four organic solvents tested in the biphasic system, 1-butanol demonstrated superior performance in terms of HMF production. When combined with NaCl, the 1-butanol/H2O system achieved an impressive HMF yield and selectivity of up to 73.8 %. Although the yield and selectivity of HMF in the biphasic system of 1-butanol/H2O-NaCl were lower than those in the DMSO system, we selected the biphasic system of 1-butanol/H2O-NaCl for this study because of DMSO's high boiling point, which complicates HMF separation after the reaction [28,29]. 3.4.2 Reaction temperature and time To optimize HMF yields, the degradation of glucose to HMF was monitored over time at various temperatures, as shown in Fig. 12. Given that the conversion of glucose to HMF involves endothermic reactions, specifically the isomerization of glucose to fructose and the subsequent dehydration of fructose to HMF [26–29], it can be deduced that higher temperatures are beneficial for HMF production according to the equation governing the reaction equilibrium constant: log K = − ∆ H ⊖ 2.303 RT + C (K: reaction equilibrium constant; ∆ H ⊖ : standard reaction enthalpy difference; R: gas constant; T: reaction temperature; C: integration constant). The results, consistent with the conclusion and illustrated in Fig. 12(A), showed that a maximum HMF yield of 49.3 % was achieved after 12 h at 120 ℃. Increasing the reaction temperature to 130 ℃ and 140 ℃ resulted in maximum HMF yields of 61.5 % within 4.5 hours and 73.8 % within 3 hours, respectively. However, due to the endothermic nature of the reaction steps involved in the decomposition of HMF into byproducts such as rehydration to LeA and FA, as well as polymerization with other products like glucose and fructose into oligomers, humins, and FA [16–23], further increases in reaction temperature led to decreased HMF yields. For example, when the reaction temperature was raised to 150 ℃ and 170 ℃, the corresponding maximum HMF yields dropped to 60.4 % within 2 h and 51.7 % within 1 h, respectively. The results of glucose conversion in the biphasic system of 1-butanol/H2O - NaCl (20 wt% NaCl aqueous solution, with a volume ratio of H2O to 1-butanol phases maintained at 1: 2 (V/V)) over the N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst are presented in Fig. 12(B) at an optimized temperature of 140 ℃. During the initial stages of the reaction, fructose, an isomerization product of glucose, was detected. Subsequently, fructose gradually underwent dehydration to form HMF or was converted into other byproducts such as LeA, FA, and humins. The yield of HMF initially increased rapidly during the reaction process, reaching a peak of 73.8 % at 3 h, after which it gradually decreased over time. This behavior can be attributed to the tandem reaction pathway involved in glucose conversion, which includes glucose isomerization to fructose, fructose dehydration to HMF, rehydration of HMF to LeA and FA, as well as polymerization reactions leading to the formation of humins (as illustrated in Scheme 4). Determining the optimal reaction time to maximize the production of the target product, HMF, is crucial. Excessively prolonged reaction times can lead to intensified side reactions and decreased selectivity for HMF. As shown in Fig. 12(B), both FA and LeA concentrations increased while the carbon balance gradually declined over the course of the reaction. Based on these observations, we conclude that a temperature of 140 ℃ and a duration of 3 h are the most favorable conditions for achieving optimal HMF yield. 3.4.3 Catalyst loading The catalyst loading is widely recognized to significantly influence the conversion of glucose into HMF. Insufficient catalyst loading hinders effective contact between the substrate and the catalyst's active sites, thereby impeding the reaction process. Conversely, excessive catalyst loading allows facile access of intermediates and products such as HMF, fructose, and glucose to the active sites, leading to undesirable side reactions and reduced yield and selectivity of HMF. Regarding the N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst loading illustrated in Fig. 13, increasing the catalyst loading enhances both glucose conversion and HMF yield and selectivity up to an optimal point. The maximum HMF yield of 73.8 % with complete glucose conversion was achieved at a 30 % N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst loading relative to the substrate glucose. However, further increases in catalyst loading beyond this point resulted in decreased HMF yield and selectivity. 3.4.4 Concentration of substrate-glucose The substrate concentration is critical for the industrial application of glucose conversion into HMF. An insufficient substrate concentration inevitably results in increased material cycling and higher energy consumption costs [28–30]. Fig. 14 demonstrates the impact of glucose concentration on its degradation into HMF. When glucose concentrations were below 10 g/L, both the yield and selectivity of HMF gradually increased with rising substrate concentration. Notably, at a glucose concentration of 10 g/L, the catalyst maintained high catalytic activity, achieving an HMF yield of 67.3 %, which highlights its potential for industrial applications. However, when glucose concentrations exceeded 10 g/L, both the yield and selectivity of HMF rapidly decreased; for example, at concentrations of 20 g/L and 40 g/L, the HMF yields dropped to 51.5 % and 23.0 %, respectively. 3.5 Stability and recyclability of N4/11@γ-AlOOH The stability and reusability of in - situ prepared N4/11@γ-AlOOH are crucial for the potential large-scale production of HMF from glucose. The loss of catalytic activity in water can primarily be attributed to two factors: (1) leaching of acid sites and (2) catalyst deactivation due to the accumulation of humins on the active acid sites [17,28–30]. To investigate acid site leaching, experiments were typically conducted using a hot filtration method [30], where N4/11@γ-AlOOH was filtered after a 2 - h glucose degradation at 140 °C, followed by an additional 4 - h reaction without the presence of the N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst. As shown in Fig. 15(A), no increase in HMF yield or further reaction was observed, indicating that acid sites did not leach from N4/11@γ-AlOOH. Furthermore, the recyclability of N4/11@γ-AlOOH was systematically investigated. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was recovered via filtration, washed sequentially with water and ethanol, and dried under vacuum at 60 °C overnight. The regenerated catalyst was then reused in subsequent reactions to evaluate its catalytic performance over multiple cycles. As illustrated in Fig. 15B, N4/11@γ-AlOOH demonstrated consistent and excellent catalytic activity, maintaining a high HMF yield of approximately 61.5 % and glucose conversion of 94.2 % even after five consecutive runs. This outstanding performance can be attributed to the exceptional hydrothermal stability of N4/11@γ-AlOOH. Additionally, XRD and FT - IR analyses were conducted on both fresh and 4-th used catalysts. The XRD patterns (Fig. S3) showed that the crystal structure of N4/11@γ-AlOOH remained unchanged after four cycles, further confirming its structural stability in the reaction system. However, FT - IR analysis (Fig. S4) revealed the emergence of additional vibration peaks corresponding to γ-AlOOH (AlO6 and (Al)OH), as well as AACH (NH4 +, CO3 2-, AlO6, and (Al)OH), on the surface of the 4-th reused N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst within the wavenumber range of approximately 3400–2800 cm−1, attributed to C-H vibrations including CC-H groups. Additionally, four peaks at around 1600 cm−1 were observed, indicating aromatic ring vibrations. These results suggest that after four reuses, insoluble polymers such as humins formed on the catalyst surface. The evaluation of NH4 + and CO3 2- leaching, along with acidity for N4/11@γ-AlOOH, is summarized in Table S2. Notably, no significant changes in the levels of N (NH4 +) and C (CO3 2-) were detected in N4/11@γ-AlOOH after the fourth reuse, implying that the in situ isomorphic substitution of ACCH into water - tolerant γ-AlOOH resulted in a stable catalyst with minimal loss of NH4 + and CO3 2-. However, further analysis indicated a reduction in BAS and LAS strength for the fourth reused catalyst compared to its fresh counterpart. Collectively, these findings, together with previous results, indicate that catalyst deactivation primarily occurs due to humins occupying active sites. 3.6 Conversion of other carbohydrates to HMF The catalyst N4/11@γ-AlOOH was evaluated for its effectiveness in converting cellulose and other carbohydrates. As shown in Table 5, the majority of the raw materials were successfully transformed into their corresponding HMFs with moderate to excellent yields. Specifically, fructose achieved an impressive HMF yield and selectivity of 85.6 % at 120 °C for 3 hours, while glucose yielded a selectivity of 73.8 % under conditions of 140 °C for 3 h. This difference can be attributed to the greater stability of the pyranoid ring structure in glucose [69]. However, the yields and selectivities of HMF from polysaccharides such as cellulose, starch, and inulin were notably lower compared to those from monosaccharides like glucose and fructose. This discrepancy is likely due to the complex glycosidic bond structures within polysaccharides [48,50,73]. The hydrolysis of polysaccharides is recognized as more complex than that of monosaccharides, primarily due to the sequential breakdown into oligosaccharides followed by conversion into monosaccharides and ultimately into HMF [48,50,51,73]. The degree of polymerization significantly influences both the stability and the difficulty of hydrolyzing polysaccharides; higher degrees of polymerization increase stability but hinder hydrolysis into oligo- and mono - saccharides. Consequently, higher reaction temperatures present greater challenges in achieving high yields and selectivity for HMF production [50,51,73]. Among starch (composed of glucose units), inulin (composed of fructose units), and cellulose (consisting of unbranched β - 1, 4 glycosidic - linked glucose units), cellulose exhibits the highest degree of polymerization [48,50,51,73], necessitating the highest hydrolysis temperature and resulting in only 48.7 % HMF yield with a selectivity of 55.8 % after a 3 - h reaction at 170 °C. Starch produces an HMF yield of 59.6 % with a selectivity of 63.7 %. In contrast, inulin demonstrates a similar HMF yield (67.2 %) when used as a substrate along with fructose. This evidence collectively indicates that N4/11@γ-AlOOH effectively catalyzes carbohydrate hydrolysis under hot water conditions, promoting both monosaccharide (glucose / fructose) and polysaccharide (starch / inulin) conversion into HMF. 4 Conclusion The work introduces an in-situ hydrothermal synthesis method for developing a facile and bi-functional solid catalyst N4/11@γ-AlOOH, which achieves a well - balanced combination of moderate LAS and weak BAS. This balance is realized through AACH isomorphic substitution of γ-AlOOH, enabling efficient HMF production from glucose. Specifically, the AlO6 octahedral units function as water - tolerant LAS with mild acid strength, while the unsaturated AlO5 pentahedral units serve as weak BAS. The study systematically investigates the correlation between acidity, structure, and catalytic performance in the conversion of glucose into HMF. It demonstrates that although LAS can enhance glucose conversion in aqueous environments, they lack selectivity towards HMF due to dominant condensation reactions leading to humins when BAS are absent. Conversely, excessive BAS can promote the decomposition of HMF into LeA and FA, thereby inducing other side reactions. Therefore, it is essential to utilize a bifunctional solid catalyst such as N4/11@γ-AlOOH that maintains an optimal balance between moderate LAS and weak BAS for the efficient synthesis of HMF from glucose. The cooperative effect between LAS and BAS depends not only on their relative abundance but also on their spatial proximity. The in - situ N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst with Lewis - Brønsted acid pairs demonstrates higher activity in glucose conversion and HMF selectivity compared to physically mixed Lewis and Brønsted acid catalysts due to its more selective tandem catalysis. Under optimized conditions using the N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalyst, a biphasic system consisting of 1-butanol/H2O - NaCl (20 wt%) at 140 °C for 3 h achieved a high HMF yield of 73.8 % with complete glucose conversion. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited excellent stability, maintaining its acidic sites without significant loss; even after five reaction cycles, an HMF yield of approximately 61.5 % was obtained along with a glucose conversion of 94.2 %. In summary, this study has provided valuable insights into the correlation between synthesis method, structure, acidic properties, and bi - functionality of in - situ N4/11@γ-AlOOH catalysts achieved via AACH isomorphic substitution of γ-AlOOH. Additionally, it offers preliminary evidence supporting the synergistic application of heterogeneous catalysis and biphasic solvent systems for the efficient conversion of cellulosic carbohydrates to bio-based furanics. coredata.dc:description: A easy-to-handle and bi-functional solid water-tolerant catalyst with the balance of Brønsted acid site ( BAS) and Lewis acid site (LAS) is crucial for the efficient conversion of glucose into 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). In the work, the AACH@γ-AlOOH (designated as Ny@γ-AlOOH) catalysts were synthesized through the in-situ AACH substitution of γ-AlOOH, where the AlO6 octahedral units served as the wate - tolerant LAS with mild acid strength, while the unsaturated AlO5 pentahedral units acted as the weak BAS, together forming Lewis - Brønsted acid pairs at molecular- level proximity. Glucose turnover and HMF selectivity were enhanced due to the rapid fructose transfer from LAS to the adjacent BAS for its dehydration to HMF, facilitating LAS liberation for another glucose turnover. Under an optimized catalyst N4/11@γ-AlOOH, a high HMF yield of 73.8 % was obtained in biphasic system of 1-butanol / H2O - NaCl (20 wt%) at 140 °C for 3 h.
